sen.j: 雅成親王（まさなりしんのう、正治2年9月11日 （1200年10月20日） - 建長7年2月10日 （1255年3月19日））は、鎌倉時代初期の日本の皇族。
sen.e: Imperial Prince Masanari (October 20, 1200 - March 19, 1255) was a member of Japanese imperial family who lived in the early Kamakura period.

sen.e: He was a son of Emperor Gotoba and his mother was FUJIWARA no Jushi (Shigeko), later, he was adopted by Senyomonin.

sen.j: 征夷大将軍源実朝が暗殺された直後、鎌倉幕府から親王を次期将軍に迎えたいとする要請が出されるが、鎌倉幕府打倒を決意していた後鳥羽上皇に拒絶される。
sen.e: The Kamakura bakufu (Japanese feudal government headed by a shogun) made a request of inviting the Imperial Prince as the next Shogun immediately after the assassination of Seii taishogun (literally, "great general who subdues the barbarians") MINAMOTO no Sanetomo, but the retired Emperor Gotoba who decided to defeat the Kamakura bakufu rejected the request.

sen.j: 承久3年（1221年）、承久の乱に加担したとして但馬国に流刑となり、同国城崎郡高屋（現在の兵庫県豊岡市）に幽閉された。
sen.e: In 1221, he was banished to Tajima Province on the charge of involvement in the Jokyu War and confined in Takaya, Kinosaki County in the same province (present Toyooka City, Hyogo Prefecture).

sen.e: However, it is recorded that he lived with his biological mother, Shumeimonin in Kyoto in 1244 maybe because of a remission from the bakufu after the death of his father, the retired Emperor Gotoba.

sen.j: その後同4年（1246年）に修明門院の最大の支援者であった当時の朝廷の実力者・九条道家が息子である将軍九条頼経と結んで、執権北条時頼とその後押しを受けた後嵯峨天皇を退けて雅成親王を次期天皇に擁立しようとしているとする風説が流される。
sen.e: Then, in 1246, a rumor that Michiie KUJO who was an influential person in then imperial court and a chief supporter of Shumeimonin colluded with his son, Shogun Yoritsune KUJO and intended to put up Shogun Yoritsune KUJO for the next Emperor by dismissing the regent Tokiyori HOJO and Emperor Gosaga who was supported by him was circulated.

sen.j: 時頼はその動きに先んじて九条親子を失脚させるとともに雅成親王を但馬高屋に送り返した。
sen.e: Tokiyori brought Kujo's father and son down ahead of their action and sent Imperial Prince Masanari back to Takaya, Tajima Province.

sen.j: 歌人としても優れており、家集『雅成親王集』がある他、『続後撰和歌集』などの勅撰和歌集にも採録されている。
sen.e: He was excellent as a poet and made the collected poems of Imperial Prince Masanari, and his poems were also included in an anthology of poems collected by imperial command such as "Shoku-Gosen Wakashu" (Later imperial poetic anthology, continued).
